dnorm( O
0 O
, O
mean=4 O
, O
sd=10 O
) O
does O
not O
give O
you O
thr O
probability O
of O
such O
a O
point O

To O
quote O
Wikipedia O
on O
probability B-W
density I-W
function I-W
In O
probability O
theory O
, O
a O
probability O
density O
function O
( O
pdf O
) O
— O
often O
referred O
to O
as O
a O
probability O
distribution O
function O
1 B-W
— O
or O
density O
, O
of O
a O
random O
variable O
is O
a O
function O
that O
describes O
the O
density O
of O
probability O
at O
each O
point O
in O
the O
sample O
space. O
The O
probability O
of O
a O
random O
variable O
falling O
within O
a O
given O
set O
is O
given O
by O
the O
integral O
of O
its O
density O
over O
the O
set O
. O

Before O

( O

( O
) O

you O

to O
go O
into O
undocumented O
land O
, O
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows O
NT\CurrentVersion\ProfileList O
has O
a O
( O
incomplete O
) O
list O
of O
accounts O
( O

' O

missing O

like O

The O

) I-D

of O

i O
: O
i+3 O
] O
for O
each O

The O

i O
: O

] O
is O
a O

that O
selects O
a O
substring. O

: O

) I-D

Fundamentally O
, O
Client B-D
Callbacks I-D
and O
Ajax O
Page O
Methods O
are O
doing O
the O
same O
thing. O
They O
use O
an O
XMLHttpRequest O
object O
to O
send O
a O
request O
( O
usually O
asynchronous O
) O
to O
some O
URL O

results O
of O
that O

then O

a O

provided O
( O
callback O
with O
a O
lowercase O
c O

results O
of O
the O
request O
to O
your O
method. O
Page O
Methods O
are O
implemented O
as O
static O
methods O
on O
your O
page. O
Your O

is O
just O

for O

really O
be O

( O
a O

service O

, O
etc. O
) O
. O

ever O

to O

I O

( O

( O

One B-D
of I-D

comments I-D
on I-D

page I-D
suggests O
serialize O

just O

unserialize O
on O

that O

Reflector B-O
, O
mentioned O
above O
is O
effectively O
a O
decompiler O
for O
the O
.NET O
IL O
, O
and O
it O
uses O
reflection O
to O

of O
the O
assembly O
contents. O
This O
appears O
to O
be O
a O
stand-alone O
product O
however O
not O
something O
that O
would O
interface O
with O
a O
C# O
program O

This O
interface O
isn O
' O
t O
based O
on O
a O
W3C O
standard. O
Instead O
it O
' O
s O
based O
on O
de O
facto O
interfaces O
from O
various O

It O
represents O
the O
object O
that O
' O
s O
returned O
when O
you O
invoke O
the O
javascript O
window.getSelection( O
) O
method O
as O

You O

NOTE O
: O

First O

" I-W

The O
function O

accepts O

arbitrary-sized O
matrix O
and O
first O

it O
into O
a O
row O
vector O

function. O
This O
becomes O
the O
initial O
" O
linked O
list O
" O
, O
stored O
in O
the O
variable O
data O
. O

, O
a O
structure O
is O
created O
( O
using O
the O

function O
) O
which O
has O
three O
elements O
: O
display O
, O

, O
and O
delete. O
Each O

these O
fields O
stores O
a O
function B-O
handle I-O
to O

function O

These O

are O

to O
access O
the O

data O
stored O
in O
the O
parent O
function O
. O
Note O

functions O

and O

matrix B-B
indexing I-B
to O

variable O
data O
. O

If O

) O

If O
the O
process O
is O
still O
running O
after O
N O
sections O
, O
call O
Process.CloseMainWindow B-D
followed O
by O
Process.Close B-D
. O
The O
docs O
for O
Process.Close O
actually O
show O
closing O
a O
process O
after O
10 O
seconds O
. O
One O
thing O
, O
though O
- O
if O
the O
process O
is O
truly O
" O
locked O
up O
" O
, O
Close O
may O
not O
actually O
shut O
down O
the O
process. O
In O
that O
case O
, O
you O
may O
want O
to O
wait O
and O
then O
call O
Process.Kill B-D
. I-D
This O
is O
a O
hard-kill O
of O
the O
process O
, O
though O
, O
so O
I O
' O
d O
recommend O
it O
as O
a O
last O
resort O
. O

recently O
answered B-P
a I-P
similar I-P
question I-P
that O
dealt O

1 O
field. O

ref B-D
RTSP/RTP O
is O
what O

to O
using O

their O

protocol. O
RTSP O
is O

control O
protocol. O
Its O
similar O
to O
HTTP O
with O
a O
few O
distinct O
difference O
-- O
server O
can O
also O
talk O
to O
the O
client O

and O
there O
are O
additional O
commands O

like O
PAUSE. O
Its O
also O
a O
stateful O
protocol O
, O
which O
is O
maintained O
with O
a O
session O
id. O
RTP O
is O
the O
protocol O
for O
delivering O
the O
payload O
( O
encoded O
audio O
or O
video O
) O
. O

So O

would O
be O
: O

to O

to O

In O

would O
be O

a O

may O

Memory O
leaks O
- O
You O
allocate O
a O
pointer O
in O
a O
method O
and O
then O
let O
it O
go O
out O
of O
scope O
without O
properly O
deallocating O
it. O
The O
pointer O
to O
the O
memory O
on O
the O
heap O
is O
now O
lost O
, O
but O
the O
memory O
remains O
allocated. O
Freeing O
this O
memory O
is O
now O
extremely O
difficult. O
More B-W
info I-W
from I-W
Wikipedia I-W
. I-W
Access O
violations O
- O
You O
create O
a O
pointer O
that O
points O
at O
a O
memory O
address O
that O
you O
do O
not O
have O
access O
to O
, O
or O
that O
does O
not O
exist. O
Pointers O
are O
just O
integers O
afterall O
, O
and O
can O
be O
manipulated O
like O
any O
other O
number. O
When O
you O
attempt O
to O
dereference O
your O
invalid O
pointer O
, O
your O
program O
will O
halt. O
More B-W
info I-W
from I-W
Wikipedia I-W
. I-W
Null O
pointer O
errors O
- O
This O
is O
a O
special O
case O
of O
an O
access O
violation. O
The O
proper O
way O
to O
" O
park O
" O
a O
pointer O
, O
so O
that O
it O
doesn O
' O
t O
point O
at O
anything O
in O
particular O
, O
is O
to O
set O
its O
value O
to O
zero O
or O
null. O
Attempting O
to O
dereference O
a O
null O
pointer O
will O
halt O
your O
program. O
More B-W
info I-W
from I-W
Wikipedia I-W
. I-W
Buffer O
overflows O
- O
You O
allocate O
a O
pointer O
for O
a O
character O
buffer O
of O
30 O
characters. O
You O
then O
proceed O
to O
stream O
user O
input O
( O
from O
a O
socket O
, O
file O
, O
console O
, O
etc. O
) O
into O
this O
buffer. O
If O
you O
fail O
to O
properly O
implement O
buffer O
bounding O
checks O
, O
then O
your O
program O
could O
potentially O
put O
more O
than O
30 O
characters O
into O
the O
buffer. O
This O
will O
corrupt O
any O
data O
stored O
adjacent O
to O
the O
buffer O
in O
memory O
and O
possibly O
expose O
you O
to O
a O
malicious O
code O
attack. O
More B-W
info I-W
from I-W
Wikipedia I-W
. I-W
Memory O
corruption O
- O
A O
pointer O
is O
just O
an O
integer O
that O
contains O
the O
memory O
address O
of O
something O
it O
points O
to. O
As O
an O
integer O
, O
pointer B-P
arithmetic I-P
can O
be O
used O
to O
manipulate O
the O
pointer O
' O

value O
in O
all O
sorts O
of O
interesting O
ways. O
Subtle O

can O
develop O
if O

pointer O

will O
now O
point O
to O
some O
unknown O

in O
memory O

and O
anything O
could O
happen O
when O
it O
is O
dereferenced O
. O

BufferedStream B-D
is O
just O
a O
buffer O
over O
an O
existing O
stream. O
MemoryStream B-D
is O
a O
buffer O
for O
the O
whole O
stream O
- O
it O
isn O
' O
t O
chained O
to O
another O
one. O
You O
can O
ask O
it O
to O
write O
itself O
to O
another O

at O
any O
time O
, O
but O
that O
' O
s O
not O
the O
same O
thing O
. O
One O
of O
the O
principle O
reasons O
for O
buffering O
is O
to O
avoid O
frequent O
writes O
to O
expensive O
resources. O
However O
, O
that O
doesn O
' O
t O
mean O
you O
want O
to O
buffer O
all O
the O
data O
in O
memory O
- O
just O
enough O
to O
avoid O
very O
small O
writes. O
For O
example O
, O
if O
FileStream O
didn O
' O
t O
have O
its O
own O
buffering O
strategy O
, O
then O
wrapping O
it O
in O

could O
end O
up O
with O
a O
buffer O
of O
only O
8K O
even O
if O
you O
write O
megabytes O
of O
data. O
As O
pointed O
out O
in O
the O
comments O
though O
, O
FileStream B-B
has I-B
enough I-B
buffering I-B
that I-B
using I-B

in I-B
conjunction I-B
with I-B
it I-B
is I-B
pointless I-B
. O

The O
fetch B-D
size I-D
is O
the O
number O
of O
rows O
physically O
retrieved O
from O
the O
database O
at O
one O
time O
by O
the O
JDBC O
driver O
as O

with O
next( O
) O

For O
example O

to O
100. O
When O
you O

first O
row O

the O
JDBC O
driver O
retrieves O
the O
first O
100 O
rows O
( O
or O
all O
of O
them O
if O

than O
100 O
rows O
satisfy O

query O
) O
. O
When O

the O
second O
row O

JDBC O
driver O
merely O
returns O
the O
row O
from O
local O
memory O
- O
it O
doesn O
' O
t O
have O
to O

that O

from O
the O
database. O
This O
feature O
improves O
performance O
by O
reducing O
the O
number O
of O
calls O
( O
which O
are O
frequently O
network O
transmissions O
) O
to O
the O
database O

db.AddParameter O
adds O
an O
output O
parameter O
in O
this O
case. O
You O
need O
to O
let O
the O
db O
client O
library O
know O
that O
you O
' O
re O
looking O
to O
get O
the O
return O
value O
back O
from O
the O
sproc O
call. O
Hence O
the O
call O
to O
AddParameter. O
db.AddInParameter O
adds O
a O
parameter O
which O
is O
only O
an O
in-parameter. O
In O
the O
It O
' O
s O
a O
shortcut O
for O
db.AddParameter O
using O
ParameterDirection.Input. O
See O
http://blogs.x2line.com/al/archive/2006/03/25/1579.aspx B-B
for O
a O
discussion O
of O
AddInParameter O
vs. O
AddParameter. O

GtkGrid O
is O
deprecated O
in O
favor O
of O
the O
more O

and O
more O
customizable O
GtkTreeView B-D
. O
It O
can O

and O

To O
make O

work O
like O

, O

will O

from O

and O

s O
for O

you O

to O
show O
, O
with O
CellRenderer B-D
s O
to O
define O
how O
to O
show O
the O
column. O
This O
separation O
of O
data O
and O
render O
allows O
you O
to O
render O
other O
controls O
on O
the O
cell O
, O

or O
images O
. O

is O

of O
the O
many O

, O

' O

the O
relevant B-D

in O

The O
duration O
for O
which O
a O
given O
vector O
will O
play O
depends O
on O
the O
number O
of O
elements O
in O
the O
vector O
and O
the O
sampling O
rate. O
For O
example O
, O
a O
1000-element O
vector O
, O
when O
played O
at O
1 O
kHz O
, O
will O
last O
1 O
second. O
When O
played O
at O
500 O
Hz O
, O
it O
will O
last O
2 O
seconds. O
Therefore O
, O
the O
first O
choice O
you O
should O
make O
is O
the O
sampling O
rate O
you O
want O
to O
use. O
To O
avoid O
aliasing B-W
, O
the O
sampling O
rate O
should O
be O
twice B-W
as I-W
large I-W
as I-W
the I-W
largest I-W
frequency I-W
component I-W
of I-W
the I-W
signal I-W
. O
However O
, O
you O
may O
want O
to O
make O
it O
even O
larger O
than O
that O
to O
avoid O
attenuation O
of O
frequencies O
close O
to O
the O
sampling O
rate O
. O
Given O
a O
sampling O
rate O
of O
1 O
kHz O
, O
the O
following O
example O
creates O
a O
sound O
vector O
of O
a O
given O
duration O
and O
tone O
frequency O
( O
using O
the O
LINSPACE B-D
and O
SIN B-D
functions O
) O
: O
When O
played O
at O
1 O
kHz O
using O
the O
SOUND B-D
function O
, O
this O
vector O
will O
generate O
a O
50 O
Hz O
tone O
for O
2 O
seconds O
: O
The O
vector O
can O
then O
be O
saved O
as O
a O
wav O
file O
using O
the O
WAVWRITE B-D
function O
: O
The O
sound O
vector O
can O
later O
be O
loaded O
using O
the O
WAVREAD B-D
function. O
If O
you O
' O
re O
going O
to O
concatenate O
two O
sound O
vectors O
, O
you O
should O
make O
sure O
that O
they O
are O
both O
designed O
to O
use O
the O
same O
sampling O
rate O
. O

Both O

create I-B

graphs I-B

but O

Both. O
Each O
invocation O
of O
a O
stored O
procedure O
( O
more O
precisesly O
each O
request O
sent O
by O
the O
client O
) O
creates O
a O
task O
in O
SQL O
, O
visible O
in O
sys.dm_os_tasks B-D
. O
Tasks O
are O
assigned O
to O
schedulers O
( O
sys.dm_os_schedulers B-D
) O
and O
wait O
until O
a O
worker O
( O
sys.dm_os_workers B-D
) O
is O
available O
to O
run O
them. O
If O
the O
system O
is O
very O
busy O
then O
the O
tasks O
will O
queue O
up O
, O
and O
this O
is O
visible O
in O
the O
work_queue_count O
column O
of O
sys.dm_os_schedulers. O
For O
more O
details O
see O
Thread B-D
and I-D
Task I-D
Architecture I-D
. O
Clients O
can O
submit O
only O
one O
request O
per O
connection O
( O
MARS B-D

Its O

GMan B-P
demonstrated O

, O

approach O
: O
scode O
contains O
x86 O

code O
which O

into O
( O
thanks O
Michael B-P
Berg I-P
) O
This O
is O
the O
code O
for O
a O
system O
call O
in O
Linux O
( O
interrupt O
0x80 O
) O
. O
According O
to O
the O
system B-D
call I-D
table I-D
, O
this O
is O
calling O
the O
sys_exit( O
) O
system O
call O
( O
eax=1 O
) O
with O
parameter O
0 O
( O
in O
ebx O
) O
. O
This O
causes O
the O
process O
to O
exit O
immediately O
, O
as O
if O
it O
called O
_exit( B-D
0 I-D
) I-D
. O
Jonathan B-P
Leffler I-P
pointed O
out O
that O
this O
is O
most O
commonly O
used O
to O
call O
shellcode B-W
, O
" O
a O
small O
piece O
of O
code O
used O
as O
the O
payload O
in O
the O
exploitation O
of O
a O
software O
vulnerability. O
" O
Thus O
, O
modern O
OSes O
take O
measures O
to O
prevent O
this O
. O
If O
the O
stack O
is O
non-executable O
, O
this O
code O
will O
fail O
horribly. O
The O
shell O
code O
is O
loaded O
into O
a O
local O
variable O
in O
the O
stack O
, O
and O
then O
we O
jump O
to O
that O
location. O
If O
the O
stack O
is O
non-executable O
, O
then O
a O
CPU O
fault O
of O
some O
kind O
will O
occur O
as O
soon O
as O
the O
CPU O
tries O
to O
execute O
the O
code O
, O
and O
control O
will O
be O
shifted O
into O
the O
kernel O
' O
s O
interrupt O
handlers. O
The O
kernel O
will O
then O
kill O
the O
process O
in O
an O
abnormal O
fashion. O
One O
case O
where O
the O
stack O
might O
be O
non-executable O
would O
be O
if O
you O
' O
re O
running O
on O
a O
CPU O
that O
supports O
Physical B-W
Address I-W
Extensions I-W
, O
and O
you O
have O
the O
NX O
( O
non-executable O
) O
bit O
set O
in O
your O
page O
tables O
. O

Microsoft O
Active O
Directory O
uses O
a O
so O
called O
server O
control O
to O
accomplish O
server-side O
result O
paging. O
This O
control O
ist O
described O
in O
RFC B-O
2696 I-O
" I-O
LDAP I-O
Control I-O
Extension I-O
for I-O
Simple I-O
Paged I-O
Results I-O
Manipulation I-O
" I-O
. O
ext/php O
offers O
an O
access O
to O
LDAP O
control O
extensions O
via O
its O
ldap_set_option( B-D
) I-D
and O
the O
LDAP_OPT_SERVER_CONTROLS O
and O
LDAP_OPT_CLIENT_CONTROLS O
option O
respectively. O
To O
set O
the O
paged O
control O
you O
do O
need O
the O
control-oid O
, O
which O
is O
1.2.840.113556.1.4.319 O
, O
and O
we O
need O
to O
know O
how O
to O
encode O
the O
control-value O
( O
this O
is O
described O
in O
the O
RFC B-O
) O
. O
The O
value O
is O
an O
octet O
string O
wrapping O
the O
BER-encoded O
version O
of O
the O
following O
SEQUENCE O
( O
copied O
from O
the O
RFC O
) O
: O
This O
is O
where O
we O
' O
re O
getting O
stuck O
... O
The O
server O
responds O
with O
a O
result O
set O
that O
includes O
the O
required O
paging O
information O
but O
PHP O
lacks O
a O
method O
to O
retrieve O
exactly O
this O
information O
from O
the O
result O
set. O
PHP O
provides O
a O
wrapper O
for O
the O
LDAP O
API O
function O
ldap_parse_result( B-D
) I-D
but O
the O
required O
last O
parameter O
serverctrlsp O
is O
not O
exposed O
to O
the O
PHP O
function O
, O
so O
there O
is O
no O
way O
to O
retrieve O
the O
required O
information. O
A O
bug B-B
report I-B
has O
been O
filed O
for O
this O
issue O
but O
there O
has O
been O
no O
response O
since O
2005. O
If O
the O
ldap_parse_result( O
) O
function O
provided O
the O
required O
parameter O
, O
using O
paged O

definition O

How O

Best B-P

You O
cannot O

way O
you O
have O
in O
your O
question. O

Why O

about O

? O
According O
to O
http://agilewebdevelopment.com/plugins/encrypted_cookie_store B-D

" O

is O

' O
s O

so O

' O

data. O

in O

session. O
" O
. O
Note O
that O

are O
multiple O
different O
EncryptedCookieStore O
' O
s. O
AFAIK O

you O
' O
s O
want O
to O
use O
Phusion B-O
' I-O
s I-O
EncryptedCookieStore I-O
and O
not O
ThinkRelevance O
' O
s O
older O
EncryptedCookieStore O

If O
you O
' O
re O
not O

cookies O

A O
mutex B-W
preferably O
runs O
in O

kernel O
of O
the O
operating O
system O
while O
keeping O

of O

around O
it O

process. O
The O
exact O
implementation O
is O
therefore O
a O
bit O
of O
a O
secret. O

' O

not O

though. O

which O
it O
gets O
and O
sets. O

the O
internal O

and O
possible O
implementations. O
Preferably O
, O
a O
mutex O
is O
controlled O
by O
the O
hardware O

thus O
making O

whole O

of O

mutex O

step I-W
. O

I O
have O

here B-B
, O

form O

something O
named O

Basically O
you O

element O
and O
property O
to O
be O
binded O
, O
as O
well O

value O

non-FrameworkElement O
object O

I O
have O
found O
another O
solution O
here B-P
, O
and O
this O
one O
seems O
to O
work. O
This O
time O
, O
the O
trick O
used O
is O
a O
DeepSetter. O
You O
define O
one O
of O
such O
setters O
as O
a O
static O
resource O
on O
the O
containing O
StackPanel O
, O
and O
then O
reference O
the O
resource O
from O
the O
behavior. O
So O
in O
my O
example O
, O
we O
should O
expand O
the O

Example O

file O
copy O
based O
solution O
: O
You O
have O
saved O

clean O
db O

its O
files O

clean_db.mdf O
and O
clean_db_log.ldf.The O

db O
is O
online O

its O
files O
are O
dirty1_db.mdf O
and O
dirty1_db_log.ldfYou O

clean_db.mdf O

dirty2_db.mdf O
and O
clean_db_log.ldf O
to O
dirty2_db_log.ldfYou O

database O
by O

sp_detach_db B-D
' O
&lt O
; O
dbname&gt O
; O
' O
; O
You O

the O
new O
files O
: O
sp_attach_db B-D
' O
&lt O
; O
dbname&gt O
; O
' O
, O
' O
dirty2_db.mdf O
' O
, O
' O
dirty2_db_log.ldf O
' O
; O
You O
delete O
the O
old O
files O
dirty1_db.mdf O
and O
dirty1_db_log.ldf O
This O
procedures O
reduces O

downtime O
between O
detach O
and O
attach O
by O
copying O
the O
clean O
files O
before O

operation O
. O

My O
application O

validation O
fails O

The O

This O

is O

in O

The O
performance O

of O

that O
can O
hit O

pretty O
bad. O

The O
JavaScript O
interpreter O
has O
some O
kind O
of O
sort B-W
algorithm I-W
implementation O
built O
into O
it. O
It O
calls O
the O
comparison O
function O
some O
number O
of O
times O
during O
the O
sorting O
operation. O
The O
number O
of O
times O
the O
comparison O
function O
gets O
called O
depends O
on O
the O
particular O
algorithm O
, O
the O
data O
to O
be O
sorted O
, O
and O
the O
order O
it O
is O
in O
prior O
to O
the O
sort O
. O
There O
are O
many O
sorting O
algorithms O
in O
common O
use O
because O
no O
single O
algorithm O
is O
perfect O
for O
all O
purposes. O
The O
two O
most O
often O
used O
for O
generic O
sorting O
are O
Quicksort B-W
and O
merge B-W
sort I-W
. O
Quicksort O
is O
often O
the O
faster O
of O
the O
two O
, O
but O
merge O
sort O
has O
some O
nice O
properties O
that O
can O
make O
it O
a O
better O
overall O
choice. O
Merge O
sort O
is O
stable B-W
, O
while O
Quicksort O
is O
not. O
Both O
algorithms O
are O
parallelizable O
, O
but O
the O
way O
merge O
sort O
works O
makes O
a O
parallel O
implementation O
more O
efficient O
, O
all O
else O
being O
equal O
. O
Your O
particular O
JavaScript O
interpreter O
may O
use O
one O
of O
those O
algorithms O
or O
something O
else O
entirely. O
The O
ECMAScript B-O
standard O
does B-O
not I-O
specify I-O
which I-O
algorithm I-O
a O
conforming O
implementation O
must O
use. O
It O
even O
explicitly O
disavows O
the O
need O
for O
stability O
. O

There O
are O
a O
few O
things O
I O
recommend O
about O
logging O
: O
Never O
use O

) O
, O

) O
, O
or O

) O

Instead O

You O

to O

or O

instead O
, O
not O
to O
mention O

out O
unimportant O
information. O

more O

and O

) O
) O
. O

Use O

question O
is O
a O
spin-off O
from O
this B-P
one I-P
. O
Some O
history O
: O
when O
I O
first O

pretty O
much O

this B-P
recent I-P
question I-P

for O

' O

to O

GLR O
parsers O
( O
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GLR_parser B-W
) O
allow O

to O

all O
of O
this O

If O

can O
write O

will O

' O

And O
a O

EDIT O
: O
Others O
have O
mentioned O
the O
session.gc_maxlifetime O
setting. O
When O

collection O
occurs O

garbage O
collector O
will O
delete O
any O
session O
data O
that O
has O
not O
been O
accessed O
in O
longer O
than O
session.gc_maxlifetime O
seconds. O
To O

time-to-live O
for O

session O
cookie O

) I-D
or O

If O

setting O

greater O
than O

greater O

equal O
to O

cookie O

VER O

.prop( O
) O

More B-D
Info I-D
The O
difference O
between O
attributes O
and O
properties O
can O
be O
important O
in O
specific O
situations. O
Before O
jQuery O
1.6 O
, O
the O
.attr( O
) O
method O
sometimes O
took O
property O
values O
into O
account O
when O
retrieving O
some O
attributes O
, O
which O
could O
cause O
inconsistent O
behavior. O
As O
of O
jQuery O
1.6 O
, O
the O
.prop( O
) O
method O
provides O
a O
way O
to O
explicitly O
retrieve O
property O
values O
, O
while O
.attr( O
) O
retrieves O
attributes. O
More B-D
Info I-D
For O
example O
, O
selectedIndex O
, O
tagName O
, O
nodeName O
, O
nodeType O
, O
ownerDocument O
, O
defaultChecked O
, O
and O
defaultSelected O
should O
be O
retrieved O
and O
set O
with O
the O
.prop( O
) O
method. O
Prior O
to O
jQuery O
1.6 O
, O
these O
properties O
were O
retrievable O
with O
the O
.attr( O
) O
method O
, O
but O
this O
was O
not O
within O
the O
scope O
of O
attr. O
These O
do O
not O
have O
corresponding O
attributes O
and O
are O
only O
properties. O

B. O
The O
low O
selectivity O
of O
the O
non-clustered O
indexes O
creates O
high O
contention O
between O
reads O
and O
writes O
( O
key O
conflicts O
as O
well O
as O
% B-B
lockres I-B
% I-B
conflicts I-B
) O
resulting O

long O

wait O
times O
for O
both O
inserts O
and O
selects. O
Possible O

be O
using O

with O
read B-D
committed I-D
snapshot I-D
mode I-D
, O

must O

of O

( O

tempdb O
) O
on O

may O

high O

stress. O

is O
using O
database B-D
snapshots I-D
for O
reporting O
, O
they O
cause O
lower O
IO O
stress O
and O
they O
can O

better O
controlled O
( O
no O

version O
store O
involved O
) O

but O

reporting O
is O

It O
' O

from I-B

cwninja B-O
unfortunately O
gave O
you O
an O
answer O
that O
will O
only O
work O
for O
accidental O
attacks. O
An O
intelligent O
attacker O
will O
have O
no O
trouble O
at O
all O
defeating O
that O
check. O
There O
are O
two O
main O
reasons O
his O
method O
should O
not O
be O
used. O
First O
, O
nothing O
guarantees O
that O
the O
information O
in O
a O
HEAD O
response O
will O
match O
the O
corresponding O
GET O
response. O
A O
properly O
behaving O
server O
certainly O
will O
do O
this O
, O
but O
a O
malicious O
actor O
does O
not O
have O
to O
follow O
the O
spec. O
The O
attacker O
could O
simply O
send O
a O
HEAD O
response O
that O
says O
it O
has O
a O
Content-Length O
that O
' O
s O
less O
than O
your O
threshold O
, O
but O
then O
hand O
you O
a O
huge O
file O
in O
the O
GET O
response. O
But O
that O
doesn O
' O
t O
even O
cover O
the O
potential O
for O
a O
server O
to O
send O
back O
a O
response O
with O
the O
Transfer-Encoding O
: O
chunked O
header O
set. O
A O
chunked O
response O
could O
quite O
possibly O
never O
end. O
A O
few O
people O
pointing O
your O
server O
at O
never-ending O
responses O
could O
carry O
out O
a O
trivial O
resource-exhaustion O
attack O
, O
even O
if O
your O
HTTP O
client O
enforces O
a O
timeout O
. O
To O
do O
this O
correctly O
, O
you O
need O
to O
use O
an O
HTTP O
library O
that O
allows O
you O
to O
count O
the O
bytes O
as O
they O
' O
re O
received O
, O
and O
abort O
if O
it O
crosses O
the O
threshold. O
I O
would O
probably O
recommend O
Curb B-W
for O
this O
rather O
than O
Net O
: O
: O
HTTP. O
( O
Can O
you O
even O
do O
this O
at O
all O
with O
Net O
: O
: O
HTTP O
? O
) O
If O
you O
use O
the O
on_body O
and/or O

callbacks O

you O
can O
count O
the O
incoming O
bytes O
and O

' O

header O

to O

for O

Curb O
is O
also O
notably B-B
faster I-B
than I-B

: I-B

The O

( O
) O

from O

I O

) I-D

Here B-B
' I-B

' O

Example O
usage O
: O

We O
are O
using O
ICU B-W
resource I-W
bundles I-W
and O
are O
pretty O
satisfied O
with O
it. O
The O
ICU O
interface O
is O
not O
" O
modern O
" O
, O
but O
it O
is O
powerful O
, O
the O
underlying O
principles O
are O
sound O
, O
and O
resources O
packaging O
( O
with O
the O
genrb O
tool O
) O
is O
pretty O
flexible. O
Its O
message B-D
formatting I-D
capabilities O
are O
also O
good O
. O
The O
ICU O
interface O
takes O
a O
Locale B-D
as O
input O
, O
so O
you O
have O
complete O
control. O
It O
also O
has O
a O
concept O
of O
" O
default O
locale O
" O
if O
it O
is O
more O
convenient O
to O
you O
. O
ICU O
has O
an O
elaborate O
fallback B-D
mechanism I-D
, O
involving O
a O
" O
default O
" O
bundle O
String O
ResourceBundle B-D
s O
( O
other O
data O
types O
are O
also O
possible O
) O
are O
always O
represented O
as O
UnicodeString B-D
, O
which O
is O
internally O
encoded O
in O
UTF-16. O
UTF-32 O
with O
UnicodeString O
is O
pretty O
easy O
, O
as O
its O
interface O

Now O
, O
as O
for O
URLs O
... O
Details O
are O
found O
here B-B
. O
Before O
sending O
an O
HTTP O
request O
, O
the O
browser O
must O
turn O
a O
URL O
( O
which O
can O
contain O
any O
text O
at O
all O
) O
into O
an O
IRI. O
You O
convert O
a O
URL O
to O
an O
IRI O
by O
first O
encoding O
it O
as O
UTF-8 O
, O
then O
representing O
UTF-8 O
bytes O
outside O
the O
ASCII O
printable O
range O
by O
their O
percent-escaped O
forms. O
So O
, O
for O
example O
, O
the O
correct O
encoding O
for O
http://foo.com/dir1/引き割り.html B-O
is O
http://foo.com/dir1/ B-O
% I-O
E5 I-O
% I-O
BC I-O
% I-O
95 I-O
% I-O
E3 I-O
% I-O
81 I-O
% I-O
8D I-O
% I-O
E5 I-O
% I-O
89 I-O
% I-O

is O

The O
first O
line O
within O
the O
while O
loop O
creates O
a O

probability O
from O
the O
probabilities O
vector. O
The O
CUMSUM B-D
function O
is O
used O
to O
return O
a O
cumulative O
sum O
along O
the O
length O
of O
the O
vector O
, O
and O
this O
is O
divided O
by O
the O
total O
sum O
of O
the O
vector O
( O
found O
using O
the O

function O
) O
. O
On O

first O
pass O
through O

loop O
, O

will O
have O
these O
values O
: O
The O
second O
line O
within O
the O
while O
loop O
picks O
a O
random O
number O
( O
using O
the O
RAND B-D
function O
) O
and O
finds O
the O
index O
of O
the O
first O
element O
in O
cumprob O
that O
is O
larger O
than O
that O
value O
( O
using O
the O
FIND B-D
function O
) O
. O
The O
roll O
value O
is O
thus O
a O
number O
from O
1 O
to O
6 O
. O
The O
if O
statement O
at O
the O
end O
of O

EDIT O
: O
Based O
on O
your O
comment O
below O
, O
it O
sounds O
like O
you O
have O
a O

image O

and O

of O
B O
by O

matrix O
A. O
This O
will O
have O
the O

of O

of O

image O

in O
A O
) O

Assuming O
B O
is O

6-by-6-by-3 O
matrix O
( O
i.e. O

rows O
and O
columns O
of O
B O
match O
those O
of O
A O
) O
, O

is O
one O

that O
uses O

( O

function O
REPMAT B-D
) O
instead O
of O
multiplication O
: O
The O
call O
to O
REPMAT O
replicates O
a O
negated O
version O
of O
A O
3 O
times O
so O
that O
it O
has O
the O
same O
dimensions O
as O
B. O
The O
result O
is O
used O
as O
a O
logical B-B
index I-B
into O
B O
, O
setting O
the O
non-zero O
indices O
to O
0. O
By O
using O
indexing O
instead O
of O
multiplication O
, O
you O
can O
avoid O
having O
to O

about O
converting O

and O
B O
to O
the O
same O
data O

Aaron O
, O

the O
stats O

" O

" O

" O

See O
here B-D
for O

commands. O
This O
will O
update O
all O
the O
relevant O
stats O
for O
the O
schema O
or O
table O
specified. O
Oracle O
' O
s O

Optimiser O
will O
use O

statistics O

which O

to O

were O
generally O

by O
releases O

but O
in O
such O

that O
could O

In O
C# O
, O
decimal B-D
numbers I-D
are O
stored O
in O
the O
decimal O
type O
, O
with O
an O
internal O
representation O
that O
allows O
you O
to O
perform O
decimal O
math O
without O
rounding O
errors. O
Once O
you O
have O
the O
number O
, O
you O
can O
format B-D
it O
using O
Decimal.ToString( B-D
) I-D
for O
output O
purposes. O
This O
formatting O
is O
locale-specific O
; O
it O
respects O
your O
current B-D
culture I-D
setting I-D
. O

For O
more O
information O
on O
regular O
expressions O
in O
Python O
, O
the O
two O
official O
references O
are O
the O
re B-D
module I-D
, O
the O
Regular O
Expression O
HOWTO B-D
. O

to O
have O
the O
result O
of O
your O
java O
version O

The O

Machines O

( O
see O
Java B-D
theory I-D
and I-D
practice I-D
: I-D
Garbage I-D
collection I-D
and I-D
performance I-D
) O
. O
So O

1.6.0_14 I-O

The O

is O

default O

See O
Here B-D

This O
regex O
matches O
all O
non-digits O
at O
the O
end O
of O
the O
string O
, O
starting O
from O
the O
last O
digit O
or O
the O
start O
of O
the O
string O
( O
if O
it O
doesn O
' O
t O
contain O
any O
digits O
at O
all O
) O
, O
and O
removes O
whatever O
is O
matched. O
More O
precisely O
, O
\D* O
is O
a O
greedy B-D
match O
for O

Concerning O
your O
clarification O
section O
, O
I O
believe O
I O
understand O
the O
source O
of O
your O
confusion. O
Traditionally O
, O
an O
object O
creates O
its O
own O
dependencies. O
Dependency O
injection O
inverts O
the O
responsibility O
of O
obtaining O
these O
dependencies O
by O
moving O
the O
knowledge O
of O
how O
the O
dependency O
is O
obtained O
outside O
of O
the O
object. O
Dependency O
injection O
doesn O
' O
t O
invert O
dependency O
relationships O
however. O
You O
may O
be O
confusing O
Dependency O
Injection O
with O
the O
Dependency B-B
Inversion I-B
Principle I-B
. O
The O
Dependency O
Inversion O
Principle O
does O
reverse O
the O
dependency O
relationship O
between O
" O
high-level O
" O
and O
" O
low-level O
" O
objects O
, O
but O
dependency O
injection O
is O
only O
concerned O
with O
how O
dependencies O
are O
supplied O
to O
a O
given O
object. O
Therefore O
, O
use O
of O
dependency O
injection O
doesn O
' O
t O
change O
how O
objects O
normally O
interact O
with O
one O
another. O
If O
prior O
to O
using O
dependency O
injection O
object O
B O
subscribed O
to O
events O
raised O
by O
object O
A O
( O
or O
vice O
versa O
) O
, O
introducing O
dependency O
injection O
will O
not O
change O
this O
. O

If O
you O
are O
knowledgeable O
about O
this O
stuff O
, O
please O

CMake B-W
: O
Welcome O
to O

system. O
CMake O
is O
a O

tools O
designed O
to O
build O

and O

software. O
CMake O

time O
( O
assuming O
good O
hash O
distribution O
) O
. O
A O
simple O
rolling O
hash O
would O
be O
the O
xor O
of O
the O
characters O
in O
the O
string O
, O
you O
can O
compute O
it O
incrementally O
from O
the O
previous O
substring O
hash O
using O
just O
2 O
xors. O
( O

Wikipedia O
entry O
for O
better O
rolling O
hashes O
than O
xor. O
) O
Compute O
the O
hash O
of O
your O
n-x+1 O
substrings O
using O
the O
rolling O
hash O
in O
O( O
n O
) O
time. O
If O
there O
were O
no O
collisions O
, O
the O
answer O
is O
clear O
- O
if O
collisions O
happen O
, O
you O
' O
ll O
need O
to O
do O
more O
work. O
My O
brain O
hurts O
trying O
to O
figure O
out O
if O
that O
can O
all O
be O
resolved O
in O
O( O
n O
) O
time O
. O
Here O
' O
s O
a O
randomized O
O( O
n O
) O
algorithm. O
You O
can O
find O
the O
top O
hash O
in O
O( O
n O
) O
time O
by O
scanning O
the O
hashtable O
( O
keeping O

simple O
, O
assume O
no O
ties O
) O
. O

one O
X-length O
string O
with O
that O
hash O
( O

hashtable O
, O

just O
redo O
the O
rolling O
hash O
) O
. O
Then O
use O
an O
O( B-W
n I-W
) I-W
string I-W
searching I-W
algorithm I-W
to O
find O
all O
occurrences O
of O
that O
string O
in O

. O

( O

Personal O

: O

personally O

" O

Definition O
: O
Hashing B-W
is O
the O
application O
of O
a O
function O
f( O
) O
to O
a O
variable O
sized O
input O
to O
produce O
a O
constant O
sized O
output O
. O
A O
hash O
function O
can O
be O
as O
simple O
as O
" O
add O
13 O
to O
the O
input O
" O
or O
complex O
like O
a O
Cryptographic B-W
Hash I-W
such O
as O
MD5 B-W
or O
SHA1 B-W
. O
There O
are O
many O
things O
that O
constitute O
a O
good O
hash O
function O
like O
: O
. O
There O
are O
many O
things O
that O
constitute O
a O
good O
hash O
function O
like O
: O
Low B-W
Cost I-W
: O
Easy O
to O
compute O
Deterministic B-W
: O
if O
I O
hash O
the O
input O
a O
multiple O
times O
, O
I O
am O
going O
to O
get O
the O
same O
output O
each O
time O
Uniformity B-W
: O
The O
input O
will O
be O
evenly O
distributed O
among O
the O
possible O
outputs. O
This O
falls O
in O
line O
with O
something O
called O
the O
Pigeonhole B-W
Principle I-W
. O
Since O
there O
are O
a O
limited O
number O
of O
outputs O
we O
want O
f( O
) O
to O
place O
those O
outputs O
evenly O
instead O
of O
in O
the O
same O
bucket. O
When O
two O
inputs O
compute O
to O
the O
same O
output O

is O
known O
as O
a O
collision. O
It O
' O

a O
good O
thing O
for O

collisions. O

to O

for O

determinism O
